title: 104_s1805
content: The Act may be cited as the "Voyageurs National Park Accessibility and Partnership Act of 1996". Congress finds that Voyageurs National Park is a unique year-round recreational unit that has been restricted in certain areas. Intergovernmental cooperation is crucial for optimizing resource protection and development, and improving the park's management and protection serves the national interest. The unique year-round recreational unit, Voyageurs National Park, requires intergovernmental cooperation for resource protection and development. This includes ensuring public access, enjoyment, and innovative management partnerships in decision-making processes. The amendment to Public Law 91-661 includes redesignating sections and inserting a new section for a Planning and Management Council. The Voyageurs National Park Intergovernmental Council, established by the amendment to Public Law 91-661, is responsible for developing and monitoring a comprehensive management plan for the park. The Council consists of 11 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from various state departments and counties. The Voyageurs National Park Intergovernmental Council consists of 11 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from county boards, city councils, State senators, State representatives, Northern Counties Land-Use Coordinating Board, and the Native American community. The Voyageurs National Park Intergovernmental Council consists of 11 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from various organizations. The Council may establish advisory committees for consultation, with a majority of members constituting a quorum. The chairperson is elected from among the Council members and serves a maximum of 2 terms of 2 years each. Advisory committees cannot receive funding to carry out the Act. The Council may appoint staff, procure temporary services, and receive administrative support. The Secretary shall provide personnel, information, and services upon request. Meetings are called by the chairperson or majority of members. The Council may appoint staff, procure temporary services, and receive administrative support. Federal agencies and the Governor of Minnesota can provide information and services upon request. The Council cannot issue subpoenas. Meetings must be open to the public with timely notice. Public notice of meetings, including time, place, and agenda, must be published in local newspapers for wide publicity. Interested persons can give oral or written statements at meetings. Minutes must be kept with records of attendees, proceedings, discussions, and conclusions. The administrative record, including meeting minutes, must be available for public inspection. The administrative record of each meeting, along with records and documents available or prepared for the Council, must be accessible to the public. New information from various agencies or advisory bodies will be considered, with interested parties given the opportunity to respond before final decisions are made. Compensation details are also outlined. The Council members serve without pay but are reimbursed for travel expenses. The Secretary will provide funding requested by the Council, not exceeding $150,000 per fiscal year. The Council members serve without pay but are reimbursed for travel expenses. The Council shall terminate 10 years after enactment, with funding not to exceed $150,000 per fiscal year. The Council members serve without pay but are reimbursed for travel expenses. The Council shall terminate 10 years after enactment, with funding not to exceed $150,000 per fiscal year. SEC. 305. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The Council must submit a comprehensive management plan for the park within 3 years of enactment, to be developed by Federal agencies, the State of Minnesota, and local political subdivisions. A preliminary report describing the plan development process is due within 1 year of the Council's first meeting. The plan must address public access and recreational use. The Council must submit a comprehensive management plan for the park within 3 years, addressing public access, recreational use, snowmobiling, campsites, trails, fish and wildlife management, aircraft access, hiking, biking, snowshoeing, skiing, watercraft opportunities, visitation at Kettle Falls, visitor distribution, and education program. The Council must submit a comprehensive management plan for the park within 3 years, addressing public access, recreational use, snowmobiling, campsites, trails, fish and wildlife management, aircraft access, hiking, biking, snowshoeing, skiing, watercraft opportunities, visitation at Kettle Falls, visitor distribution, education program, and wilderness management for certain areas of the park. The Council must also comply with relevant environmental laws, consult with various agencies and organizations, and conduct public meetings for input. The Council must submit a comprehensive management plan for the park within 3 years, addressing public access, recreational use, wildlife management, and visitor distribution. The plan cannot include removing park designation or allowing certain types of development. The Council is required to report on water levels in the Rainy Lake Watershed to the International Joint Commission. The plan must be submitted for review to the Secretary and Governor of Minnesota. The Governor of Minnesota may comment on the comprehensive management plan for the park within 60 days of receiving it from the Council. The Secretary must approve or disapprove the plan within 90 days, considering public participation and assurances from State and local officials in Minnesota. The Secretary must approve or disapprove the comprehensive management plan for the park within 90 days, considering public participation and assurances from State and local officials in Minnesota. If the plan is disapproved, the Secretary must notify the Council in writing of the reasons for the disapproval within 30 days. The Council must revise and resubmit the plan to the Secretary within 60 days of disapproval. The Secretary will then approve or disapprove the revised plan within 30 days. The Council is responsible for reviewing and monitoring plan implementation, allowing for public comment and modifications. The Council may modify the plan with approval from the Secretary if necessary. Before plan approval, the Council must work with governmental entities to minimize adverse impacts. The Secretary is restricted from issuing regulations related to the park, except for routine business and emergency regulations, until the management plan is approved. The Act does not affect the State of Minnesota's jurisdiction to enforce laws, tax entities, or regulate fish and wildlife in the park.
